titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Visit from Mr: Schermerhorn. Walk, met Messrs: Midleton, Levsen, and Bielefeld— News from France. expedition of emigrants defeated. Peace between France and Spain.— Voorhout in the Evening.
2. Read Condorcet. Essay upon the progress of the human mind, an ingenious specimen of philosophical delirium. Much pleased with it. In the Evening at Mr: Dumas’s.

3. At Mr: Moliere’s in the morning. Subscription for Amsterdam paper. Walk. Met Mr: Uribarri who informed me of the Peace between France & Spain, confirmed by Messrs: Levsen & Bielfeld. Papers from America.
4. Letter from Captain Barney at Flushing. Rainy day. There have been but two fair summer days this Season— To see Mr: Dumas in the Evening. Voltaire’s Pucelle d’Orleans in course.

5. Mr: Pitcairn dined with us and Mr: Houghton. Young Van Son here. Houghton has got into a difficulty from which he will not be readily extricated. Endeavoured to see Mr: Paulus. He is gone to the Texel.

6. To see Mr: Van Eck. Not in town. Went to Mr: Veerman’s. found in the Schuyt a Monsr: Monfort, a french clergyman going there also. Passed the day tolerably. Walk with Madam. Music. Returned at night by the Schuyt. found Pitcairn at the house when I came back.

7. Mr: Dumas, and Mr: Veerman dined with me. The latter obliged to go away immediately after dinner. The old Gentleman stay’d and paraded republicanism as usual. Long Walk after he was gone. Visit from the Bielfelds.

8. Captain Rice here. Walk; met Mr: Uribarri; who seems well pleased with his Country’s Peace. At Mr: Van Swinden’s towards Evening. He is a member of the Committee of Marine. Conversed on the subject of Houghton’s business; and of Cowing. Great professions of regard, friendship, attachment to the United States; of disposition to gratify me personally; but most dear determination to confiscate Houghton’s property and keep Cowing in prison.
Went to lounge at the play. Condemned to hear Paul et Virginie through.
9. Short walk in the morning. Met Mr: Uribarri. My brother went in the afternoon to Mr: Veerman’s. Long walk towards night; met nobody, weather fine.

10. Bielfeld called to see me. Walked with him in the wood. Met his brother without pleasure. His temper is uncomfortable. At the play in the Evening; for time must be passed, and it is impossible to read or write forever. Les deux fermiers, a dull Comedy. L’Italienne a Londres, with music very good. The play an absurd paraphrase of the Ecossaise.

11. Wrote to Messrs: Willink, Van Staphorst and Hubbard. Read Mirabeau’s letters to his Constituents. They appear to be dull and factious. Nor can all their ardour give importance to events, which were essential only as they were preparatory to others.

12. Saw Mr: Van Son upon the subject of Houghton’s business. Sent him the Law of the United States upon the remission of penalties incurred without intention or wilful negligence. Appeared before the Court of Justice to give evidence of an affair which occurred in the wood last evening, and to which I was considered as a witness; I saw however nothing material. The Judges requested me however to draw up in writing a declaration of the facts as I had witnessed them, which I accordingly did. It was merely a quarrel or fighting match which from what I saw in the wood might be presumed had been; but which I did not see.

Mr: Spaen called to see me, and informed me of my admission to the Society. All this has been entirely independent of my knowledge, except from what Count Lowenhielm told me at M: D’Araujo’s the other day.— Met Mr: Spaen again in the Evening.

13. Went this morning to the greffier Quarles’s, and conversed with him respecting Houghton’s affair. He had little to say about it. This man does not gain upon one’s esteem on acquaintance. The great Governor of human affairs is Routine. Quarles before the revolution of 1787. held a subaltern office of clerk to the States-General. after that event he was driven to resignation, and now by another revolution he is thrown into an Office, which was once important: it may be so still, but if it is, it must be very indifferently filled.

Called again at Mr: Van Son’s; who shew me the second petition he had drawn for Houghton: he has used the law of the United States which I mentioned to him, and sent him yesterday, as an argument to obtain a similar favour in this instance. The petition was this day presented and referred again to the Marine Committee. I have less sanguine hopes than Van Son in this case.

14. Writing, but not very industriously. Read Voltaire’s Epistles, Stanza’s and Odes. Walk this afternoon to Scheveling. Sat half an hour upon the downs. Music in the Evening with Mr: Parker. Weather warm. Visit this day from Mr: Van Heukelom of Leyden; from Mr: Dumas also.

15. Dull weather. Walk in the wood towards night; afterwards in the Voorhout. Met Mr: Van Swinden; conversed with him upon Houghton’s affair and that of the man arrested at Flushing. Endured his complaisant harshness and his hard words, as well as his unfeeling reflections.

16. Letter to Mr: De Wolfe; in part to the Secretary of State and to Mr: Bourne. Visit from Mr: Bielfeld, and walk with him in the wood. Walk again to Scheveling towards Evening; weather fine. Full of Company.

17. Mr: Houghton brought me a letter from Mr: Bromfield at London. Rainy weather; the principal part of the Day. Walk alone to the barrier towards night. Music this Evening.— Visit in the morning from Mr: Lambrechtsen, & Madam van Polanen.

18. Dined at Baron Schubart’s. Madam Van Polanen there and Mr: Lambrechtsen. Mr: De Roure an aid de Camp to M. de La Fayette. Walk with Bielfeld to Scheveling; upon the downs. Music at home. Letter from Mr: Johnson London.

19. Bielfeld called on me; we went to see Mr: Parker’s pictures. Walk afterwards. To Leydsendam in the afternoon on foot having miss’d the boat returned by the boat in the evening. Babbling french soldier amused us on the way.

20. Walk in the wood. Evening at Mlle: Lorenzi’s. Music. Cards. play’d quadrill. The company altogether unknown to me. Voltaire Volume of Epistles &c. the former volume was of Poems. In these several sorts of composition he seldom rises much above mediocrity.

21. At home till the Evening. Walk then in the Voorhout and round the town. Weather warm and sultry: some music with Mr: Parker: subject much to the dulness of indolence. Lessons of flute instead of something else to do.

22. Visit in the forenoon from Bielfeld. Walk with him in the wood. Met Mr: Levsen. An impatient moment, that was wrong. Mr: Dumas came in the afternoon and told me that he was triumphant, & had got the obnoxious resolution erased from the Journals of the States General. Thunder shower.

23. My brother went to Visch Lust. Visit from Mr: Bourne. from General Eustace who appears to be excessively embittered against the french Government. Walk towards Evening to Scheveling.— Translation of the 1st: Elegy of Tibullus.
24. Count Löwenhielm called here in the morning. Went with him to the Society. Walk in the wood towards evening. Met Bielfeld. Continued the walk with him till late; the weather beautiful.

25. Early dinner and went in the afternoon to Visch Lust. found Mr: Montfort there. Walk with Madm: Veerman. Music. returned by the 8 o’clock boat. Music all the way
Weather very fine. On my return home found a Letter from the Secy. of the Treasury, and from Mr: De Wolfe.

26. Letter from the Presidt. of the bank of the United States. Wrote Messrs. Willink Van Staphorst & Hubbard. In the afternoon music with Mr: Parker. Visit from Mr Reutenswerd. Voorhout in the evening. fine weather.

27. Long walk in the morning with Bielfeld. Again in the Voorhout in the Eveng: Met Mr: Van Hogendorp there. Walk with him. On returning, found Mr: Allis, and Mr: Soren who brought me a letter from Mr: Otis.

28. Visit again from Mr: Soren this morning, and gave him a Letter for Messrs: Willink. Letter this Evening from Mr: Van Son. informs me that Houghton’s second petition to the States General is rejected. The Empson and Dudley practice of reviving obsolete penalties and making the penal laws a snare to the unwary seems to be adopted and pursued by the present Government here. It has been done at least in this instance. An old law, which had long been without execution prohibits the importation of foreign cloth broad cloths into this Country; the penalty is confiscation and the profit principally for the fiscal of the admiralty the official informer. Since the Revolution a Man by the name of Deutz has been put into the office of fiscal. Greedy, indigent and rapacious, his first object is to hunt for the benefits of confiscations. He laid his hand therefore upon Houghton’s property, which he had brought there upon the faith of a long established practice which tho’ contrary to Law had been connived at or pass’d without notice by the Government. Upon this ground Houghton presented his two petitions. Upon the occasion of the first I applied to Mr: Paulus President of the Marine Committee, to whom the petition had been referred; he assured me that permission would be given to carry away the articles. But I found soon after that the marine Committee had sent the petition to Deutz the fiscal for his advice. When the party the most deeply interested is formally made the judge of his own cause, its issue can be easily foreseen; Deutz was applied to by Mr: Bourne in favour of Houghton: he promised he would favour him as much as possible, and even to make a report favourable to him. Made his report full and decided against him, and then denied his own promise to Bourne. The same course was pursued in the second petition. The members of the marine Committee promised wonders, but sent the petition to Deutz for advice. Deutz, pretending that he had reluctantly followed a rigorous duty in his former report, and that he would shew his disinterested benevolence in the second, reported as before; the Committee has done the same, and the second petition meets with the fate of the first.
29. Fine Weather. begun a letter to my father.— At the Society.— Music in the afternoon with Mr: Parker.— Become more and more useless.

30. Spent the day in doing nothing. Went towards night to Mr: Scholten’s, found there the two french Generals M’Donald and Darville, Mr: Levsen, and Mr Girard from Amsterdam. M’Donald is going to Zeeland. The other General has just arrived here. He was for more than a year before the death of Robespierre in prison and was not delivered till after the famous ninth of Therdimor. He related several anecdotes respecting his imprisonment, which agree in general with the other accounts that are now given of that time.— Voltaire’s Letters in verse. Vol: 17 of his works.
31. Visit in the forenoon from Bielfeld, and walk with him. Walk again, alone in the Evening.— Tibullus.
